regretList.regret: I wish I would have taught my children better habits when it comes to their own health and wellness.

I resigned my job because my dad was going to die soon and I thought I’d be able to spend quality time with him. He died before my resignation took effect, and I did not ask for my job back. Fifteen years later, I still have feelings about not being invited by my employer to rescind the resignation, given the timing of my dad’s death.
getting married young (age 20)
I regret not continuing my piano lessons. I can play things through repetition, but I never gained the experience and knowledge necessary to become proficient.
Not studying abroad in college
1 theft charge at 17 years old. Minor punishment but record of crime follows me around despite being an upstanding citizen for the past 30 years. My Divorce.

I regret not waiting for my high school sweetheart.  He left for the Navy before I graduated high school.  It was so hard for me.  He was the only one in the world I felt loved me. I grew up neglected and longed for love.  I hated to see it go and I felt it was over once he left.  I chased loving feelings and started up with someone I could see and touch, although I loved him.  We talked as adults and he told me that he had every intention of marrying me, I told him that I wish he would've told me that at the time; but I can't be sure it would've made a difference.  I am glad that we had a chance to talk about this as adults though.  I apologized to him.  I didn't even consider how much I had hurt him with my actions, I selfishly only considered how I felt when he left.  He told me that he did it for us.  He wanted to be sure he could take care of us.  He's happily married, the guy I left him for is happily married.  I am sad and alone.
Not taking my undergraduate education more seriously.
I once hit my Dad..He NEVER hit me !

I have been fostering dogs for a local rescue since 1999. I have fostered literally hundreds of dogs. I was asked to foster a dog whose owner had died, she had lived with another dog also. I went to get her and bring her home and I was somewhat scared of her but she seemed to get along with my dogs fine. I went to work the next day and decided to come home at noon to check on everybody. That dog had killed one of my dogs and mortally wounded another, who was my little princess. I regret not listening to my instincts and bringing that dog into my house. I continue to foster for that organization, they were certainly mortified and as regretful as I was.

Should have climbed mountains when I was young and had healthy knees. I waited for the opportunity to fall in my lap, instead of recognizing that there was a component of having to work for it. Everything worth doing comes at a price, but eventually the opportunity can pass you by.
I regret not taking my son with me when I left his Dad. I signed away custody so that his Dad could no longer control me. That one decision has controlled every thought and action I've had since. :(
I wish I would have committed suicide when I was 18
I didn’t date the nice smart guys who actually liked me, just the ones who were challenging and unsupportive.

When I was in 8th grade, our small, rural school participated in the National Spelling Bee for the first time ever. I excelled at spelling. In the competition to choose the winner from our school, my boyfriend and I were the final contenders and I purposefully misspelled the word "scissors" in order to let him win. I have regretted that ever since.
Not achieving more with the the time and opportunities I had. Not being closer to family that is far away.
I regret not telling my stepson I loved him and hugging him more before he died. I regret not checking on him the night we heard the loud noise.
not being more aggressive in my youth
Not going to medical school.
Being too hard on my son when he was young.
I regret not learning how to stand up for myself after listening to my gut and walking away from a relationship that ultimately ruined my life.

I regret not being in more student clubs in college and being a total nerd and just focusing on studies and saving money. I would have had a much better experience If I was braver and tried more things. For e.g. I never went to a college football game or a college basketball game and I went to Indiana University Bloomington, home of the Hoosiers, when Bobby Knight was there!!!
Saying no to a date with a man I found attractive.
Not learning to speak up for myself sooner

My biggest regret is that I did not understand nor was I emotionally mature enough to make better relationship decisions. It resulted in not having relationships I wished I had and having a relationship that was unhealthy because we got pregnant early on, got married and tried to make it work. It didn't work and was largely miserable for ten years. I was blessed with three great kids, but the marriage was a beating. Thank God I finally got free of that and have found real love and a healthy marriage.
I've started romantic relationships without thinking about it much and ended up with heartbreaks.

Not spending time with my son before he went to college. I'd met someone new and needy finally after my divorce, and I spent every chunk of time my son would've been at my house with my new beau instead.
I should have waited to get married, maybe never married, but certainly later.
Should have divorced my first wife and raised my kids with much more involvement to be successful.

I regret not executing a plan I had work on for two years to move to England. I paid thousands of dollars in legal and had a job and a work visa in 2007. I stayed in town because of a man, the dream of being together and building a company together. I wasted 12 years and he abused and manipulated me. It lost the years, but learned the lesson.
Getting out of a bad career choice sooner (didn't leave soon enough).
I wish I had pushed myself to continue my doctorate degree.
Not maintaining fluency in French as my second language.
I regret that I didn't learn more about finances from a young age.
I regret not monitoring my childrens' weight more closely when they were young.  It would have saved both of them considerable heartache as they grew up.
Being unfaithful
living life instead of working har
I regret not keeping in touch with extended family when I moved to another state.
I regret not getting a college degree.
I regret not speaking to my grandparents more before they passed away.
spanking my child

My biggest regret is not saving for retirement sooner.  I should have "bit the bullet" and contributed first and I probably would have been in a better place now, in turns of finances.  The other item is that "quit" trying to get into Medical school.
Not enough focus as a high schooler/college student (too much other stuff).

I wish I had kept myself in shape.
I wish I had started saving more earlier in my life vs. being the ‘life of the party’ or experiencing “FOMO” before it was described as “FOMO” today.

I can see things in 3D and wanted to become an aircraft mechanic and attend the highly prestigious George T. Baker Aviation School in Miami, during my high school days. Instead, I went off to university and never got my hands dirty or the chance to fix airplanes.
pursuing a career path that i was "Expected" to take. not the one my heart told me to take.
That I did not complete law school when I had the opportunity and rather choosing to become a warrior in the business world and living my life for others rather than live my passion.
I regret not moving in with my mother for what turned out to be the last year of her life.

Mi esposo me fue infiel en una época de nuestra vida en común, cuando permanecía un promedio de dos semanas fuera de la ciudad, por su trabajo. Después de muchos años, no logro librarme del arrepentimiento de no haberlo sacado de mi vida.
Not setting boundaries with certain people

I only have one regret in life and that is not seeing my grandmother despite her asking me to come visit. She and I lived together for 6 months when I returned home from college while I was looking for a job. I got a job and she moved to my uncle’s house. My uncle’s family and I didn’t have a great relationship so I didn’t enjoy going to their house. She asked me many times to come visit but I told myself and her that work was so busy and the 12-hour shifts tiring. Two months later she passed. Wish I had the maturity at 22 to have set my feelings of discomfort aside for her and go see her.
Not learning Spanish

In 1996, I was studying abroad in Florence and I ended up responding to a sign in a local window "models wanted". Over the course of maybe a month or two, the artist painted me. The end result looked as much like as I did but the vibe/feel was exactly me. It was uncanny. But I wasn't a wealthy American student. I didn't have the money to buy it. It sold within a few months to a tourist couple from Paris. I have always regretted not buying it.
I did not take proactive steps that would have assisted my 20 year old brother during his battle with cancer.

When I was a sophomore in college, my Dad called as I was coordinating weekend plans with friends.  Since I was going to see him the next morning, I rushed the conversation and went off with my friends.  He had a heart attack and died before I got to see him.  I have always regretted not having more of a conversation with him that night.

Getting married.
Not being focused in school.
I regret not understanding and appreciating how short childhood is. I wish I would have savored every chaotic, stressful, challenging moment recognizing this time is one and done.
Early in: I regret judging my children. Later on:  I regret not listening carefully to my children when they were in emotional pain
That I didn't really listen to my children.  Trying to be a good parent instead of just loving my children.
Not seeking help at a younger age for my abuse
i honestly have no regrets in my life

location.country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland

regretList.regret: I had a party at my house when I was 16 years old and my parents were away. The house got trashed and my mum and dad were upset. I really wish I hadn't done this.

location.country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland

regretList.regret: Having low self confidence and esteem and allowing it to damage relationships with my wives, partners (too many but all wonderful people) but especially my daughter. Not realising what wonderful parents I had until long after they passed. I had focused on the (few) things they didn't do right rather than the many things they did excellently and the love they had for me.

location.country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland

regretList.regret: a relationship i didn't pursue

location.country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland

regretList.regret: I have a wonderful husband and family but regret failing to maintain close friendships from my past or establishing any meaningful friendships local to me. Socially I feel lonely and wonder if this is how I will feel for the rest of my life.

location.country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland

regretList.regret: Not saving for the future. I don't know when I will be able to retire

location.country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland

regretList.regret: Getting married when I knew in my heart the relationship was already over

location.country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland

regretList.regret: My friend found out her newborn had a disability. I got the text about this when I was in the hospital having my own baby. I did not call her until something like a month later. She never wanted to speak to me again. I should have called her right away.

location.country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland

regretList.regret: I am almost 60 and only recently has it been realised that I have severe ADHD.  This means that I have been misdiagnosed for over 40 years.  The effect on my life trajectory has been catastrophic.  I am in crisis with life in chaos and multiple mental health diagnoses (that I'm medicated for) I have said for years that the drugs don't work but they just kept giving me more. I still have huge problems with everyday life.  Hopefully, things will improve for me now,  but it is too late to make up for my chronic lifetime underachievement.

location.country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland

regretList.regret:
not staying in Japan
moving to Luxembourg

location.country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland

regretList.regret: My regret is not following my passion early on in my career, instead, I was chasing the money.
I regret not trying harder in school
Not completing Bachelor's

I did not truly recognize that we get one shot at this thing--and who knows how long our one shot will be. I have wasted time; I didn't value learning history when I was younger; I did not prioritize travel. In other words, I kept the world too small.
Spending so much time worrying about what others thought of me instead of doing things that brought ms joy.
Spending time in an abusive relationship

I am a 18 year old college student that is currently procrastinating on an assignment. I usually do all my class work in the afternoon and I am a morning person should be doing my online class work in the morning.
Settling for complacency and time spent looking back not forward. Not expressing justified anger.
Choosing fear over love.
I regret not spending enough time with my friends back in Chicago.
I wish I had not spent so much time being fearful - just lived with abandon and not cared if I measured up or how others thought of my behavior or person! Just go for it!

Growing up, I wish I had been kinder to my mother about her hearing loss. She wore hearing aids and I often had to repeat what I said. I was rude about it. Now, I find my hearing diminished and have to ask people to repeat themselves. Hearing aids help some, but I miss a lot. I really understand now what my mom went through.
I was not honest with a high school boyfriend and broke up in a very heartless way. His mother had been very good to me and I never said good bye to her. I have regretted this for years.
not being smarter in my career
I regret that I regret almost everything!
I regret being scared of girls in high school.  I missed out on so much because of it.
I regret that I did not promote myself more.
Something I regret is staying longer then i should.
Time is the only thing you can’t get back. Time I should have spent listening to my mother and grandmothers stories while holding their hands.

I regret not looking for a life partner sooner.  I focused on becoming independent, and didn't really start dating until my late 30's.  At 46, it's really hard to find someone with whom to have a shared fate, common goals, someone to grow old with...I'll never regret being independent (emotionally and financially), but the older I get, the more I realize, the best things in life are shared.
I hugely regret not addressing my fears and learning about financial wellness early enough. It is very hard to "catch up" in your fifties.
Not going on a travel abroad trip when I was in high school and college.  Or taking time to travel the world after high school or college.
Not getting my masters sooner

I regret that it took me so long to realize that  you can't control what other people think of you. And it's none of your business what they think, anyway.  Wish I'd learned it in my 30s or 40s rather than my 60s.

I regret wasting my health and my time on people who did not matter and who hurt me. I spent so much of my energy, my youth, and my well-being on on my job, rather than on my family. I stayed at work until 10-11 pm, worked on weekends, instead of spending that time with my son, my parents, my family. I will never get those back.
I regret not taking more time to just relax. I was always on to the next "thing" to do.
Letting my college sweetheart get away.
I should’ve identified and taken action on what i really want out of life
Ending abusive relationships early on, rather than putting up with abuse. Wish I had believed that I deserved better and taken action.
I did not stay in high school instead quit in 10th grade. Completed my equivalent diploma almost 20 yrs later. Began college 15 years after that. I’m still in college now.
I regret not listening to my inner voice more instead of following what I was told was "right".
Marrying my husband.
I wish i didnt let my parents (Deaf) depend on me as much as they did as a kid
Not trying harder to stay married to my first husband because of the impact that divorce has on kids.

I was in greater Tibet and nomad invited me to come with him, he gestured over the hills, off the road, to who knows where. I was on a schedule to go back to school but my mind has created infinite scenarios on where that journey would have taken me.

I wish I would have pursued a doctoral degree when I was younger.  If I had spent more time talking to professors when I was in undergrad then maybe I would have found one to inspire/encourage me.  As a first generation college student, I had no idea of what to do after college other than get a job.  I could have been a professor, done research to help make the world better, and collaborated with other thinkers across the world.

While in Utah some years back touring the National Parks, we stopped at Delicate Arch but did not hike all the way to the rock formation for various reasons. I wish I had taken the time. (This is symbolic of other choices I've made in life to not take the time to experience some location/event.)
I married a bum -  first marriage. I put him through college.
not eating better
I regret that I quit the corporation that I had formed. It was doing well.  I needed mentors and had no where to turn when I needed help.
I regret that I married the woman to whom I am married

I always loved holding my mother’s hand. After she passed away, I was unable to hold it one last time. She’s been gone over nine years and I regret not taking the opportunity to have physical contact with her for a final time. At 56 years old, I miss holding my mom’s hand.
I regret not appreciating my mother until she was gone.
Not untangling my upbringing more definitely and sooner.
I regret getting married too early and having kids too soon — I had a job I loved and had to leave it. I’ve always wondered what if I stayed?
That I didn't stick with one company and advance my career in one place instead of jumping from organization to organization to end up working in over 50 companies.
Not dating Nikki

I regret being too impatient to allow my kids to help me in the kitchen with cooking. Now as young adults they don't have any cooking skills or even know how to peel an apple, and not much interest to be in the kitchen.
I wish I would have been more attentive to communicating effectively and compassionately with my two ex-husbands, so we could have avoided divorce.
I should have gone to college sooner.  I didn't go to college and earn a degree until I was in my 40.
I wish I had known that it wasn't me that was wrong/fucked up (in my family and relationships) all those years.  Reading Untamed by Glennon Doyle set me free.
choosing not to have another child
I regret not establishing healthy lifestyles habits in my life earlier on.
not going to medical school and becoming a doctor; my personal experience as a 10 years old spending 3 months in a hospital away from my family changed my mind about becoming a doctor

I regret that I did not travel across the country to meet my large extended family until I was over 50 years old. I missed out on meeting some wonderful people who had already passed away and who may have greatly enriched my life. I missed out on half a lifetime of love and connectedness to people who share my family history.

I’m 4th generation half Chinese. I regret not learning Mandarin as a child. I regret the fact that my family didn’t keep more cultural ties or connection to our family back in China. I can’t blame my grandparents, though - family is complicated and assimilation during the early 1900s was a b*tch.

I loved hiking and camping as a kid and young adult, and I love spending time being active and adventurous outdoors, but it is not a big part of my current family life. I regret not being more proactive in establishing traditions with my husband and kids around spending time living and playing and adventuring outdoors. My husband is happier with comfort and cleanliness and predictability and ease when we vacation or travel, and I have deferred to his preferences rather than insisting on my own. Now in my 50s, with teenaged kids, I feel like I missed out on some joyful experiences and memories, and missed the opportunity to gift these to my kids as well. Blah. :-(
not enough leisure time

That I didn't ask more questions.  To my parents.  About their life.  To people I didn't meet.  As in...I didn't talk to them!  I may have stood next to them but I never engaged in a conversation.  What could have happened?

Marrying my ex husband. He was from another culture and I knew it would be difficult. I didn’t know how to stop it. His family was against the marriage and I knew that. I had a bad feeling before the wedding but I felt I had to go through with it.
Concorrer a um cargo político no Brasil. Trouxe -me endividamento, decepções e constrangimentos. A minha pior experiência na vida.

I regret not letting my heart be broken at a young age. I feel as if I've closed myself from the world too early and it has taken me a long time to realize that and try and open back up, which as we get older it becomes more and more difficult.
Casar-se muito cedo
Have more courage to do the things. Example: talked with girls without fear to be rejected, be more religious (find good)
I did not leave sobab when I was not integrated there
Not going out for exchange

I regret for not having gone to Australia when I was 24-year old. Ben and I met on the summer of 2004 in Santorini and fell in love, but both lived far away to each other. He planned a trip to South America to visit me, but was cancelled then he invited to go to Australia. I feared to go.
Overwelmed stong pass for The time protect and defend the helm protect The king

I regret to have taken some decisions in my life in a hurry. I think some of them could be done differently and I had suffer less with my decisions. However, it's okay because I learned a lot with these precipitated decisions and now I know that our life is a beautiful learning school.
Not taking care of my health during pregnancy - it affected my child that was born 6 months old premature.

I regret not having the confidence in my own dreams and ambitions when I was younger.  I always wanted to write and 30 years later am coming back to it.  I just wonder what I could have done if I'd stuck at it then.
Taking the pill for so many years and not listening to my body. Not speaking my truth, e.g. to my loved ones, therefore again disappointing myself instead of others

being to hard
lack of empathy
Persuing an undergraduate degree that does not match my true interests.

Ter tirado uma formação 
Seguir sem medos do que realmente quero
giving too much confidence to friends who didn't deserve it; trust people too much
Falling in-love too easily
With the context and choices at concise moments, can not find relevant regrets!
I  have regrets towards my dog. He died due to my negligent care.
Listening to my dad when actually he was just letting out poisninous anger
I regret some of the things my children heard me say to their father.

I was a fast runner in grade school and we moved in 5th grade to new a town that had a competitive running team.  I caught bronchitis in the first year and couldn't keep up so I never went back to the team.  I regret that dropping out made me miss out on having the experience of being part of an athletic team in high school.
Not believing that my unique qualities were actually my strengths and gifts.
I wish I had appreciated the short time I had with my great-grandmothers more when I was a kid. Now I would give anything for 15 minutes.

Ignoring warning signs and noticeable clues regarding my ex-wife when we dated years ago and thinking things would be better if we got married. We were married 15+ years but then divorced 11 years ago. It's a regret I was young and dumb and proud.

I DEEPLY regret not having admitted to myself that I am a Lesbian SOONER.  Instead of wasting years dating the wrong gender I could have been falling in love with the right one and having a much happier life.
Getting student loans.

I know this seems silly but I regret not upgrading to business class on a flight from CA to IN when I had the chance. I was 16 and it was only $30 but I thought my dad would kill me if I spent it on a seat upgrade rather than something else. To this day, I have never flown business class.

I had an opportunity for an internal move with my company.  At the same time I worked with a mentor/coach that recommended not telling my current supervisor about the opportunity for fear that he would try to stop me from making the move.  I regret not telling my supervisor because the decision caused long term damage to the relationship.
Not taking the path of playing pro baseball.
Not starting a significant professional path earlier in life

Years ago, I broke into my high school and stole some tests. A year after graduating, I was having lunch with a teacher who had thought highly of me and I shared/bragged about it because I thought it made me look smart. After I spoke, I could tell it broke her heart.

I regret I didn’t follow up on a teacher’s recommendation and investigate going to Georgetown University to study history. Instead I went to a nearby university. It lowered my sights and kept my world small.

I regret not giving my mom a big hug when we were out shopping for wigs and clothes to help her feel better about her cancer-ridden body; she was not one to share too much about her feelings, and made a passing comment revealing she was struggling with feeling good about herself. Our relationship was not one of ease, and I wish I would have opened my heart and genuinely connected with her in that moment.  This was 26 years ago, and she died less than a year later.
I regret being so mean to people in High School. I had a terrible home life and took that out on people. I wish I would have reached out for help instead.
I regret not feeding my dog. I also regret being on this planet.
I regret not being by my mother's bedside when she died. I was instead standing by my father across the room from her.
I regret cheating on tests in college. I was smart enough to study and pass but chose social time over study time. Even with cheating, I was still an average student.
I've always been risk adverse and therefore my life has been calculated to mitigate negative outcomes. Maybe more free-falling is the key to "living"?

I regret that when my grandmother died when I was 12 that I didn't understand that I should spend more time with my grandfather and chose to be uncomfortable enough to avoid going to their house. It was so painful for me, but I can't even imagine how much more painful I made the situation for him by not going over as often.
All my regrets are related to things I wish I would or wouldn't have said to people I cared about, and/or for time I didn't spend with peopleI care about that I can no longer spend time with.
Not trusting my own initial reactions or visceral responses more often. That first blink is usually pretty accurate.
I regret choosing to stay with an emotionally abusive man just because I’d made a vow.
Poor financial decisions such as taking out student loans to fund my education are one of my biggest regrets. I did not seriously look for other ways to pay for my undergraduate and graduate degrees.

I regret not spending more time with my parents. They've both passed away. I can't count the number of times I've said, "I wish mom was here to show me XX or help me with XX" or "I wish dad was here to explain how I'm related to XX or advise me about XX." Not only do I wish I'd spent more time with them, but I also wish I would have filmed them answering questions about our family.

A couple was in the process of adopting two boys from another country asked what they might expect, given that the babies had been abandoned, were infants, and early care was unknown, I responded too curtly.  I said that the children may well have learning and behavior problems.  Who can predict the future?
Going into education as a career. I was a first generation college student and there were teachers in my family so I did what I had been exposed to.
I regret putting so much emphasis on my career when my kids were young. Spending extra time working to advance my salary instead of spending that time with them when they were young.
That I never realized I could make my money work for me verses working hard for my money
I regret not getting post high school education.    This lack affected my confidence and always made me feel inferior.

I regret not going on more dates.
I regret getting married to the first person I met.
I put up with a master bully boss for too long which eroded my confidence, performance and health.
Missing out on the love of my life

Staying in a crap relationship instead of accepting an exchange opportunity in another country in university. 

Marrying my second husband. Relates to regret one above.  Best thing about it was I had my beautiful son.
I regret marrying my husband.
Helicopter parent

I regret not finding a way to buy my family cottage when my parents had to sell it. I didn't appreciate until recently how much of my identity, my sense of place, and my connection to friends and family was tied to that modest cottage on a clear freshwater lake.
I they not having spoken to my grandparents more about their experiences when they first came to North America from Sweden.
I regret not being diagnosed and treated for ADHD earlier in life.
I regret getting into drugs and dropping out of college.
A combination of things: becoming a nurse, then moving to the States.

Not enjoying the blues more. Was always drunk at the Blue Note instead of really going to enjoy the music. Didn't go to the Stevie Ray Vaughn concert in Kalamazoo (by myself and to a far and distant land) about a week before he died in an accident. Drunk both but that's because I was too fearful.

I never should have bullied Larry in Junior High School. He was effeminite and introverted making him an easy target. I was proud of him for hitting me over the head with his three-ring binder, believe it or not. I apologized to him and stopped others from bullying him. But, the sad fact is it never should have happened in the first place. He was, and is, a human being, with all the rights to be treated with respect, empathy and kindness. He accepted my apology graciously, but I will forever be ashamed by my actions.

In 2006, I had the opportunity to interview for a contract UX designer position at LinkedIn. At the time, I wanted to work from home and not in an office - for no good reason, really. I canceled the interview. I still ask myself, what if I would've gotten that job and then converted to FT?

Regret sometimes = GUILT vs. missing an opportunity or wasting time and energy in the wrong things. Right now I feel regret/guilt for not doing all of activities my Mom wanted me to do with her recently (travel, backpacking/hiking, etc.). She has cancer now and we won't likely ever get to have those adventures together again.
I have recently lost my sister and although we spoke for hours on the phone, i regret not taking a bus up to see her in person.

Allowing my then-husband to decide that I should be the one to get out of the service instead of him so that we could be geographically together.  I bowed to societal pressure to be submissive as a wife and a female and as a result, I missed out on a fantastic opportunity to pursue my interests and be independent.
Not becoming a nurse.

I took crib notes into exams all throughout my high school and college years.  This has bothered me f my whole life, since I started almost 50 years ago.  Except for this, I have led a very honest life.  I just never learned how to study properly.  I have never shared this with anyone and would feel so ashamed if my own children ever found out.  My wife died several years ago and I never shared this with her.
I regret not being more confident and pursuing my dreams with more intention.
I wish I would have not given up on pursuing who I believe was the love of my life.
I had the opportunity to purchase a professional baseball team when I was 23. The cost was $100,000 in 1984 and I just wasn’t smart enough at that age to dream big.
I regret losing contact with friends from the different chapters of my life

Not having the confidence to leave my place of employment to pursue higher levels of responsibility when it became evident it wasn’t going to happen where I was.  I had a great job at a great company. But I watched equally talented people get the big jobs at other firms and I regret not doing the same.
I let my Mom nap.  I should have tried to wake her up.  She had had a stroke.
I regret not telling Jenn that I had a crush on her.  I was too worried about our friendship and am left wondering if we could have been really good together.

I regret playing it safe right out of college and getting a practical job, instead of following my dreams and traveling the world, student loans be damned. I'm in a great financial place now, but years of comfort and stagnation have made me fear change. I fear I'm too old to do the whole "vagabonding" thing now.
I regret taking my first drink at 15 that led me down the path to a lifetime of alcohol abuse.
Not getting my mental health issues addressed sooner.  Then maybe I would have been able to meet a nice person to spend my life and have a family.
Not majoring in computer science in 2009. My life would have been in a different place. Well now I am self-studying CS. Let's see where this un lived life takes me.

I regret not finishing my college degree, even though I needed very few credits to do so. The company I was working for part-time offered me a full-time position, and I jumped at the chance to get a substantial promotion, make good money, and launch my career.

I went to an elite UK university, won a scholarship while there and looked set to go on to an academic career. That was my dream. But on the first day of finals I totally lost my nerve, panicked, missed the exams and went AWOL for a couple of days (regret 1). After tracking me down, my parents persuaded me to go back and complete the rest of my exams, which, out of guilt I did and so ended up with a mediocre degree (regret 2) - quite an achievement in the circumstances, I guess, but devastating for an incurable perfectionist like me. If only I'd either had the courage to turn up for the exams on day one and taken my chances or stuck to my decision to drop out at the 11th hour and saved myself further humiliation. But I did neither. I took the coward's path - twice in succession. They say you regret the things you didn't do more than those you did. But my 'sin' was both of commission and omission. After 40yrs, it's a double wound that has never healed. Time, you are not a great healer!

There was a sign on it that said ‘keep out’. After feeding the cat for a while and becoming attached as it learned to trust me (slow process), I decided he needed a nickname of sorts. He became Keep Out from there and we grew to be great friends. He would eventually start coming right to our apartments door for his daily meals. He learned the feeding schedule and always showed up on time. I loved this cat and wanted to make him mine, but my husband and I already had 4 cats of our own. I regret not taking him in or at the very least catching him and taking him to a shelter. My husband and I finally got a house and moved out of state. I regrettably had to leave him behind. I think about him so often and I hope he found a loving and safe home. I miss him terribly.
